title: I just discovered a way to sing a high note, but the right side of my throat hurts after singing. What's the problem? - Quora

response.answer_text: If anything in your throat hurts from singing, you sure as hell are doing something VERY wrong! It is hard to tell from a “disembodied” medium such as Quora (meaning not in-person/live), but I suspect that the discomfort in your throat is the result of asking too much of it whilst asking too little from the rest of your voice, particularly the supporting apparatus, the breath and breathing mechanisms. Pain in the “throat” most often means the larynx, where the vocal folds (cords) are, but can also mean the muscles in the neck surrounding. Neither is acceptable! Most likely, you are pushing your “throat” (as described above) to do all of the work, and do it “off the breath,” which is to say without proper - perhaps any - breath support. That being said, you need to learn to sing “on the breath,” which isn’t nearly so daunting as it may sound. It’s a discipline, one which is readily taught and learned, and also essential to not only singing, but also speaking. A good, basic teacher of voice can teach you how to do this. But you really can’t learn how to do it on-line. Period. It requires live interaction. If we think that Renee Fleming or Lady Gaga or Pavarotti or Josh Groban (those are just the names that popped to mind while waiting for my coffee to finish!) make those sounds entirely with their throat, we are operating with some serious misinformation! Good singing - and I don’t care if it’s opera, rock or anything in between or betwixt - involves the entire body and mind in the process. If it is a passion, it is worth finding a really good teacher and learning the classic, essential basics of singing, of properly functioning vocal production. It doesn’t matter what kind of music you ultimately wish to sing: a singer must have a strong basic vocal technique.

Thanks for the A2A. There are a few possibilities: You may not be providing adequate support. One thing I always check in my own singing, and certainly in that of my students, is muscle tension in the throat resulting from inadequate breath support. Proper air supply and appoggio (breath prop) is necessary to relaxed, strong singing higher noted.You may have a technique flaw that creates tension. Does your singing have vibrato? My go-to singing “maxim” in this: “Vibrato is the natural, inevitable result of relaxed, supported singing. When the vibrato goes, it’s usually a result of absence of one or both conditions.” If you’re fatiguing because of lack of support, your vibrato (or lack thereof) could be an indicator.You may not have good posture. Look, there’s always tension somewhere in the body. Usually we learn to make use of it in constructive ways—for instance, tension in the hips both helps us stand upright and provide good foundation upon which to produce appoggio. But it’s not unheard of to climb up the spinal column and wreak havoc with singing.You may just be singing literature that’s too high.” No one wants to be told they’re in the wrong literature, but it’s something to consider. Just because you have high notes does not necessarily mean you’re vocally fit to sing a ton of them. It’s not unheard of for mezzo sopranos to have the same range as a regular soprano, but that doesn’t mean the range is equally comfortable. Similarly, I’ve sung with baritones with enormous ranges, but that doesn’t mean it’s going to be easy singing tenor literature. Having high notes doesn’t always mean you have a higher voice. How long can you live among those notes?If you’re not studying with a live voice teacher, I encourage you to search one out. Sometimes it takes an external set of ears and a candid, knowledgeable authority to give best guidance. If you are studying with a teacher, ask about working on relaxing warmup techniques.
